title: 107_s587
content: The Act titled "Sustaining Access to Vital Emergency Medical Services Act of 2001" establishes the Rural Emergency Medical Service Training and Equipment Assistance Program under the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities to improve emergency medical services in rural areas. Eligible entities include State emergency medical services offices, associations, offices of rural health, local government entities, ambulance providers, and other entities approved by the Secretary. Applicants must submit an application to the Secretary to receive a grant. Entities eligible for grants to improve emergency medical services in rural areas must submit an application to the Secretary, including a description of activities and assurance of compliance with matching requirements. Funds received must be used for emergency medical service squads in non-metropolitan or rural areas as defined by state laws or regulations. The grant program, established on February 27, 1992, allows for funding to hire, recruit, and train emergency medical service personnel, acquire vehicles and equipment, and develop new educational methods for healthcare providers. The grant program, established in 1992, provides funding for emergency medical services personnel to acquire personal protective equipment and educate the public on CPR, first aid, and emergency preparedness. Preference is given to collaborative applications and those intending to fund activities outlined in the grant. Matching requirements apply for grant eligibility. The Secretary may only grant funds to entities that agree to provide non-Federal contributions equal to 5% of the grant amount. Emergency medical services refer to resources used outside medical facilities under emergency conditions due to patient conditions or natural disasters. The authorization of appropriations for emergency medical services includes funding of $50,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2007. The Director can allocate up to 10% of the funds for administrative expenses. The Director can allocate up to 10% of the funds for administrative expenses. SEC. 3. PRUDENT LAYPERSON STANDARD FOR EMERGENCY AMBULANCE SERVICES UNDER MEDICARE AND MEDICAID. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act regarding ambulance services for Medicare Fee-For-Service beneficiaries and Medicare+Choice enrollees. The regulations now specify that ambulance services should be considered medical services even if the ultimate diagnosis shows they were not necessary, as long as the request was made after a sudden onset of a medical emergency. Amendments to the Social Security Act include changes to ambulance services in Medicaid Managed Care Plans, with the effective date applying to services provided after the Act's enactment.
